text.p: American Jenny Thompson upstaged pre-race favourite Misty Hyman on Saturday by shattering the women's 100 metres butterfly short-course world record at the world short-course championships.
Thompson surged through the final length of the 25-metre Scandinavium arena pool to touch in 57.79 seconds.
China's Cai Huijue (57.92) and fellow-American Hyman (57.95) both chased her home inside the previous mark of 58.24 set by Japan's Ayari Aoyama in Tokyo on March 28.
It was Thompson's second gold of the four-day championships following her victory in the 100 freestyle on Thursday and a silver in the 50 freestyle on Friday.

Hyman, world record-holder at 58.29 before Aoyama, treated the crowd to her spectacular submarine style, emerging at the end of the first length for a last obligatory stroke above the surface after diving in and turning on her side under water.
Hyman swam just six strokes above the surface on the second and third lengths and seven on the fourth.
She led handsomely at the 50-metre mark, going through in 26.55 to Thompson's 27.02 but Thompson and Cai caught her on the last length.
It was Hyman's third bronze following third places in the 200 butterfly and 100 backstroke.
